heading: intel invests in svg
subheading: intel has acquired a minority share in a silicon valley chip technology company that is working on new ways to make smaller chips.
author: wired news report
text: intel on tuesday made a multimillion-dollar investment in a silicon valley company. the two will work together on designing next-generation processor chips. intel spent us$15 million for a minority share of the silicon valley group.based in san jose, california, the silicon valley group designs production tools for chip manufacturers, including intel's competitors.the silicon valley group said it is developing a process that will shrink circuits to only 157 nanometers -- one nanometer is one-billionth of a meter -- which is approximately 60 percent smaller than the 0.25-micron process used to manufacture intel's current line of processors.by reducing component size, more of them will be able to fit on a chip's surface, resulting in faster, less-expensive chips."smaller, faster, cheaper, better is where it's at," said russ weinstock, silicon valley group's chief financial officer.like lithographic printing presses, the photolithography process uses light to imprint circuits on silicon wafers. it is the most-common technique currently used in chip-making.
